risinfo.booktitle: Companion Animal End of Life Care for the Veterinary Technician

para.emphasis: Companion Animal Euthanasia Training Academy, Lutz, FL, USA

sect2.title: 13.1 Introduction
sect2.para: Assisting caregivers with the handling of their deceased pet is a special part of a veterinary technician’s job. It is an honor to care for the pet patient in life and carry that forward in death, even in small ways. Respectful deceased body care has evolved significantly in recent years. The standard for decades was the traditional practice of placing a body in a refuse bag and telling caregivers what their options are. Today we have matured into using designated, branded cadaver bags and putting caregivers in control of how they want to memorialize their pet. The hospice industry has been a big driver in this paradigm shift, in part because of the extra attention given to the human–animal bond and simply asking caregivers what’s important to them.

In a 2021 study, caregivers were asked about the things that matter to them the most during the loss of a petch0025-c13-bib-0001. Not surprisingly, many shared how important it is to know their pet’s body is being treated carefully and with love. For those who find it hard to say goodbye to the body, the unknowns can be alarming. Table 13.1 shows some of the more common concerns expressed by caregivers once their pet leaves their side. Some of the bigger issues center around how much time it would take for the pet to arrive at the aftercare facility and how people would be handling the body. Mislabeling the body and missing special memorialization requests were also worrisome for many. The least concerning detail was whether deceased pets would be in close proximity to other deceased pets, indicating that there is an acceptance of this normal protocol in veterinary medicine and perhaps even a benefit as the pet is not alone.
Table 13.1 from the 2021 pet aftercare study showing what’s important to caregivers and their concerns.

To better align with what caregivers desire and expect after the death of their pet, pre‐death discussions about such matters should increase confidence and understanding. Technicians who talk through options and inform on what is normal in aftercare services give some semblance of control to caregivers during a time when they feel they have little. They did not want their beloved pet to die, wishing instead to continue being together. Whether through euthanasia or a natural passing, the death is forcing a new “normal” upon them, and having control over aftercare choices becomes an important next step in the grief journey.

sect2.para: Veterinary technicians in general practice, specialty centers, emergency rooms, and mobile hospice services have a unique opportunity to shine during aftercare discussions and preparations. As partners to the family or individual caregivers, technicians are able to talk openly as friends to learn what’s important, and to follow through with requests to not only meet the expectations of owners but to exceed them. Technicians are commonly tasked with managing aftercare details which range from discussing locally available options, collecting payments, preparing the body, and contacting the aftercare company to relay requests. Generally speaking, technicians are comfortable working with both living and deceased animals, having gone through similar anatomy and procedural training as veterinarians. With adequate communication skills, technicians are equipped to have hard conversations around death and aftercare.

sect2.title: 13.2 Aftercare Ordering Models
sect2.para: There are two ways in which aftercare arrangements may be made following the death of a pet. The first and more traditional way is to have the veterinary team be the liaison between the caregiver and aftercare service. The second and more modern approach is to invite the caregiver to take the lead on aftercare decisions and arrangements directly with the aftercare company. Both approaches have pros and cons. In the coming years, the animal hospice industry will likely help shape the best ordering model that makes sense for the caregiver, the veterinary team, and aftercare personnel.

sect2.title: 13.2.1 Veterinary Aftercare Ordering Model (VAOM)
sect2.para: This model relies on the veterinary company to order aftercare services on behalf of the caregiver. Technicians are often tasked with informing caregivers of their choices, recording wishes for their deceased pet following death, collecting payment for aftercare requests, and ordering such services through the aftercare company. In this way, the veterinary company, rather than the caregiver, becomes the client of the aftercare company and is ultimately responsible for carrying out what the caregiver expects. This model lessens the pressure placed on grieving caregivers to understand the nuances of aftercare services. Instead, the seasoned veterinary team can act as funeral directors, making arrangements on the caregivers’ behalf, which is something they have likely done for countless clients. The downside is that caregivers are typically only informed about the options the veterinary team wants to relay. More aftercare options may exist that caregivers miss out on because they do not know about them. This model also requires a clear chain of custody by the veterinary team to safely ensure the deceased patient is handled correctly without mistake.

sect2.title: 13.2.2 Client Aftercare Ordering Model (CAOM)
sect2.para: A new aftercare ordering model has been emerging that invites caregivers to work directly with the aftercare company. This model places aftercare decisions in the hands of caregivers, allowing them increased choice and opportunity to learn what an aftercare company offers, without the pressure of making decisions just before or during euthanasia. Following the death of the pet, caregivers can take time to make their aftercare choices (e.g. private cremation, urn selection, paw print keepsake). This model places caregivers in the unique position to fully understand their options and mirrors human death care much more closely. Caregivers who opt for advanced care for their pet at the end of life may appreciate more aftercare control. The difficulty with this model occurs when caregivers would prefer to not make such decisions and would rather rely on the veterinary team to handle all arrangements for them. However, 45% of caregivers claim to already know what they wantch0025-c13-bib-0001.

sect2.title: 13.3 Respectful Body Containment
sect2.para: Whether caring for deceased pets in specialized end‐of‐life (EOL) care or general practice, veterinary staff have an obligation to handle the body with respect. Caregivers want to know their beloved pet was treated with the same dignity and respect shown to humans, especially when they have received such care and attention during the EOL journey ch0025-c13-bib-0002. Technicians are well‐suited to ensure deceased patients are lovingly handled and will safely reach their destination. In conversations with technicians over the years, this author has heard many express the desire to see patients cared for as well as their own pets, and that doing so improves job satisfaction.

When death is confirmed and caregivers have left the area, technicians may begin to prepare the body for aftercare. The body containment vessel (e.g. cadaver bag, casket, or basket) is brought into the room and the body is gently placed inside. This requires effort to support all parts of the body as it is lifted and moved into position. Depending on the type of containment, absorbent pads may be placed under the body to collect fluids. By doing this preparation in the room where the patient died, the body will already be concealed when moving it to the holding area in the hospital or out of the home. This reduces the visualization of death by other personnel/people and prevents the spread of disease.

Trash bags, or plastic bags that resemble them, have been the standard containment style since the mid twentieth century (seeFigure 13.1). They are purchased from hardware or retail stores or from veterinary supply distributors to hold the bodies of both large and small companion pets. It can feel uncomfortable and disrespectful to place an animal in the same type of bag used for waste, as if to convey that once deceased the body no longer has meaning. While trash bags were the norm, veterinary teams rarely placed pets inside them in front of owners, perhaps out of embarrassment or disapproval of having nothing better. Trash bags easily puncture, especially with long toenails, and tend to tear and leak bodily fluids. While the cost of trash bags is minimal, a more respectful body container is important to caregivers and trash bags are no longer accepch0025-c13-bib-0001.

In recent years, body containment options have been evolving into something more akin to human aftercare. Designated, branded cadaver bags such as Euthabag© were designed to be specifically used for companion animals (Figure 13.2). Created by Canadian veterinarian Dr. Celine Leheurteux, Euthabags are leakproof, puncture‐proof, and meant to be shown to clients. Deceased pets may be placed in them with loved ones watching if they desire, and the body is then taken home for burial or for transport by the caregiver to the crematory. It is acceptable to have the caregiver help place the pet inside the bag and the hospital holds it for crematory pickup. The goal is for caregivers to be as involved as they wish and for the veterinary team to feel proud of the container they are using. Bags such as Euthabag may be decorated with tribute messages and artwork of significance to the family, making them an attractive option for children who want to participate (Figure 13.3).

sect2.para: Pet caskets are another option for body containment. They range from simple cardboard caskets to more elaborate ones sold by pet funeral homes and online stores (seeFigure 13.4). Technicians may want to research casket options to better understand the cost and typical delivery speed. Caskets may be kept in storage ready for use, especially the cardboard variety, or they can be ordered as needed following the death of a patient. As a general rule, caskets are a highly personalized specialty item that won’t be for everyone. While caskets are typically ordered for burial use, they can be used to hold a deceased pet for viewings and before cremation or aquamation services.

Other respectful body containment ideas include human cadaver bags for large breed dogs or companion livestock. There are washable pet cadaver bags such as Clay Creek©, and some hospitals prefer washable baskets for deceased pet holding. The most important elements to consider are how well it contains odor and body fluids (preventing the spread of disease and environmental contamination with hazardous drugs) and whether the caregiver would approve of how their pet is contained (see Table 13.2). Odor can be lessened by adding odor absorbers and scented oils such as lemon and eucalyptus, both of which help to repel insects. The company Shiva Shade© specializes in odor and fluid management and can be a useful resource for veterinary technicians.

sect2.title: 13.4 Moving a Deceased Body
sect2.para: A deceased body behaves differently than a living body, and this is never more evident than when a technician handles their first deceased pet. Care must be taken to protect the body from harm and treat it with the utmost respect, especially when caregivers are present. Deceased bodies will need to be moved by the technician for a variety of reasons, including being placed in body containers such as body bags, being placed onto stretchers for removal to another location, being lifted into coolers for preservation, or being carried in one’s arms to wherever the body needs to go.

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 13.1 Unexpected Sounds from Deceased Animals
sidebar.para: When moving a recently deceased pet’s body, there is a rare occurrence that can be surprising or even disturbing for the observer. If there is any remaining air in the stomach or lungs, it may move over the pet’s vocal cords when their body is handled, thus creating a sound. This can be shocking to nearby people, as it may falsely cause them to believe the pet is still alive. While this is not common, it is something to be aware of so that it may be calmly recognized and explained to any observers. Death can be reconfirmed for the comfort of everyone present.

emphasis.emphasis: When Moving Deceased Pets, Consider the Following Tips

listitem.para: Move the body as if not to wake it from deep sleep.
Support the head and neck to prevent it from falling or the tongue protruding out.
Keep the head elevated to prevent fluids from escaping.
Keep absorbent pads/material under the body as body fluids or gas may be expelled. Urine in particular may begin to flow as soon as the body is moved (Pro Tip 13.1).
Determine how much body weight can be lifted by one person and plan accordingly to have stretchers and other carrying devices ready for heavier pets (seeFigure 13.5).

sect2.title: 13.5 Modern Options in Aftercare
sect2.para: Technicians will have a considerable number of options to review with caregivers related to aftercare. Taking time to review what’s available will be an important part of the animal hospice experience. Caregivers have varying levels of aftercare knowledge, and much will depend on whether they have gone through the loss of a pet before. Technicians who know a great deal about local aftercare company offerings are valuable assets to the team and will make the planning and preparation phase of the process much smoother for grieving caregivers.

Canada’s Seneca Polytechnic College, in partnership with VCA Canada Animal Hospitals, produced a useful document called Pet Loss Best Practice Guidelines for Veterinary Teams (2020). They suggest assigning personnel such as technicians to become “Client Aftercare Specialists” who can perform six important tasks for loved ones needing to make pet aftercare decisionsch0025-c13-bib-0003.

listitem.para: Stay current on aftercare and memorialization products and services. In a growing and changing market, new options are emerging frequently and in order to ensure clients are aware of the different options available, staff must first be informed.
Organize a product and service guide in both print and digital formats to create accessible means to share information with clients.

Provide options to clients earlier in the care and treatment plan. This could be done through noninvasive and nonthreatening ways such as posters, pamphlets, and printouts, which are constantly available in clinics.

Ask clients if they have a preferred aftercare provider and assist them in this decision‐making process. Clinics are encouraged to stay informed of all options in their region to ensure clients can make informed decisions about their pet’s aftercare.

Form relationships with all local services to advance the clinic’s ethical approach to care. Include cremation services that offer both pickup and receiving clients directly with their pets. Inform clients of burial bylaws or stipulations in their region. Alternatively, direct them to the resource they should contact to explore that option.

Spend time with the family discussing all aftercare options so that clients do not feel rushed and are provided with ample time to discuss options. Provide families with a flexible yet reasonable amount of time to confirm their aftercare decisions after they leave, in case they need more time to process options, or in the event they change their minds. Some clients are not ready to make a final decision about remains at the time of death. Provide clients with written and/or digital information they can review after leaving; verbal communication is not always sufficient.

sect2.para: These recommendations are a good example of how to gain the necessary knowledge to support caregivers and lead them toward positive aftercare outcomes. The concept of a Client Aftercare Specialist can be leveraged within any animal EOL care service, making this person a priceless member of the team. They will be the go‐to person to answer more complex aftercare questions and help train new team members as the service grows.

The common theme found in pet aftercare resources for veterinary professionals focuses on the need to be informed about facility operations and to allow caregivers to choose what is important to them [ch0025-c13-bib-0002, ch0025-c13-bib-0003]. The cost of aftercare can be a factor, but it should not be what drives a veterinary company to select one aftercare company over another, it should be the quality of care given to the deceased pet and loved ones ch0025-c13-bib-0004. People who work in aftercare tend to really appreciate the opportunity to engage with caregivers and exceed their expectations. Many would prefer to work directly with the caregiver when given the chance.

For the majority of caregivers, the fundamental goal will be for technicians to arrange for their pet’s body to be converted from one form (the body) to another form (ashes or remains). The whole body is no longer needed, in fact, it is unsanitary and unsafe to keep it in most instances. The caregiver needs a timely option to remove the body and dispose of it or alter it to become a safe and lasting memorial (e.g. cremated ashes). The latter has been done for centuries as a means to keep a part of the animal close and keep memories alive.

sect2.title: 13.5.1 Cremation
sect2.para: Cremation is the process of using fire to reduce a body to ash. This takes place in an oven or “retort” specifically designed for this purpose. All soft tissue in the body is burned away and what remains is the bony skeleton, and perhaps metal implants if they were surgically placed during the course of the pet’s life. Many people do not realize that ash is bone without any other parts of the body. Technicians may explain this early in the decision‐making process.

The cremation of a body may be conducted in a few ways and each crematory will have policies around how a body is cremated. Caregivers will need to be told about these policies, so they fully understand what they are choosing.

listitem.para: Private cremation: A procedure during which only one animal’s body is present in the cremation unit during the cremation process.

Partitioned/semi‐private/segregated/individual cremation: A procedure during which more than one pet’s body is present in the cremation chamber and the cremated remains of specific pets are to be returned to the caregiver. Due to a number of factors and by virtue of multiple pets being cremated within the same unit at the same time, active commingling of cremated remains will occur.
Communal/group/scatter cremation: A procedure where multiple animals are cremated together without any form of separation. These commingled cremated remains are not returned to owners.

sect2.para: The Pet Loss Professionals Alliance (PLPA) and the International Association of Pet Cemeteries and Crematories (IAOPCC) have similar definitions as those listed above. There is some discrepancy around the term “individual” among crematory companies. If this is not carefully clarified with the crematory, veterinary teams and caregivers may think a private cremation is being done, when in actuality an individual cremation is being performed. Caregivers who believe they are only receiving their pet’s ashes may be upset to find that their pet was in the cremation chamber with other animals. Comingling of ashes may occur, meaning a pet’s ashes could contain fragments of another’s. The best approach is to ensure caregivers understand what is taking place, so they make highly informed decisions (Communication Corner 13.1).

Caregivers may ask if special items may go with their pet’s body for cremation. Whatever goes into the cremation chamber will be burned along with the body. Bulky items such as comforters and large stuffed animals produce a considerable amount of debris that will become mixed with the ashes, which the caregiver may not like. Depending on what the items are made of, such as plastic and rubber, the crematory may decide not to cremate them to reduce hazardous gas emissions. Technicians who know what can and cannot be cremated with the pet’s body can relay the information to the caregiver. Special arrangements may be made if the caregiver wants an item to go with the pet but wants it returned intact with the ashes (e.g. favorite toy, picture of the family, and a note from a child).

sidebar.title: Communication Corner 13.1 Example Language to Explain Traditional Cremation

listitem.para: “Cremation uses fire to reduce away the soft tissue, leaving only the bone behind.”
“Once the bone is cooled, it will be ground down into ash, which resembles a small gravel appearance.”
“The ash will be returned to your family in an urn of your choosing, or it may be spread on your behalf.”
“Cremation takes up to an hour or two, however, it may take a week or more before ashes are returned.”
“Your pet’s special items may be cremated with them as long as the crematory allows.”
“He doesn't need his body anymore, so we are going to change it into something different. This only happens after death.”
“Cremation uses heat, very very hot, to change his body from what you see now, into ash. Ash is made from bones that have been made smaller and smaller.”
“If you would like to see what ash looks like, I can show you some.” (Have a small bag of ash ready to show. Adults may appreciate this too.)

sect2.title: 13.5.2 Burial
sect2.para: Pet burial is an option for caregivers and is sometimes preferred over cremation. Burial may feel more natural as it is a slower, more controlled body reduction over time. Caregivers may choose burial at a pet cemetery or on private property including their own. Depending on where the caregiver lives, a home burial may or may not be allowed. Rules around burial tend to include how close the burial proximity is to town/city boundaries, if it’s close to a flood plain or water source, and the size of the body. While regulations vary widely between towns, states, provinces, and countries, a few key burial recommendations are commonly found when reviewing burial guidelines.

emphasis.emphasis: Common Pet Body Burial Recommendations for EOL Care Teams, to Be Included in a Handout or Accessible Online, are

listitem.para: The body must be placed underground deep enough to be covered with at least 3 ft of earth (4 ft down ideal for most small companion animals) (see Figure 13.6).
Beware of buried utility lines and tree roots.
Ensure proper permission to bury at the site.
Avoid flood plains or areas where water regularly pools.

sect2.para: Home burial guidelines should be given to caregivers anytime they remove an euthanized body from the veterinary team’s care. This includes if they express the desire to bring the pet to the crematory facility themselves. Caregivers may change their minds and opt for burial instead. Informing them of proper burial guidelines will help ensure the body is safely managed, preventing harm to wildlife and the environment (Communication Corner 13.2). Pentobarbital sodium, a common euthanasia solution, is a poison and has been linked to the death of scavengers ingesting the tissue of euthanized animals ch0025-c13-bib-0005. Leaving an euthanized body above ground for scavengers and natural decomposition, a practice known as sky burial, is unsafe and should be avoided. If it is known that burial is the goal, veterinary teams may opt to avoid pentobarbital altogether and utilize a different euthanasia agent (e.g. magnesium sulfate, potassium chloride, lidocaine).

sidebar.title: Communication Corner 13.2 Example Language Related to Proper Burial

listitem.para: “Since you will be keeping him for burial, let’s talk through how to do that safely.”
“His body will have euthanasia solution in it, which is dangerous to wildlife and other animals. We’ll need to make sure his body remains protected and untouched.”
“While the plan is to take him to the crematory yourself, let’s review burial guidelines just in case you change your mind and want that instead.”
“Please sign here stating you understand how to safely bury your pet.”

sect2.para: It is important to make mention of rabies testing for mammals and the ramifications for burial. There will be instances when a mammalian patient has bitten a human and will be euthanized before the mandatory 10‐day rabies quarantine period expires. In regions of the world where the rabies virus persists, governmental agencies may require the pet’s head to be removed and a sample of the brain tested for the virus. This means that the body and head will be separated. If caregivers wish to receive the body back to conduct a home or cemetery burial, they should be told about this physical change. This is to prevent a tragic discovery during a very emotional time. A leakproof, fully concealed bag or vessel should be provided for transport to the burial site.

Pet cemetery burial is an option in some communities. This is typically arranged by the caregiver and cemetery staff together. The veterinary team’s only role may be the transport of the pet’s body to the cemetery, keeping the body tucked as small as possible for easier placement in the burial vessel. Payment for cemetery burial is rarely managed by the EOL care service and tends to be considerably more expensive than cremation or aquamation. This is due to the long‐term management required for pet cemetery burial, including grave site care and internment guarantees given to the caregiver. A direct relationship between the cemetery and the caregiver without veterinary staff involvement is the best approach.

sect2.title: 13.5.3 Aquamation
sect2.para: Using water and alkali salts to reduce a body to ash is gaining popularity around the world. Known formally as alkaline hydrolysis, aquamation (also called water‐based cremation, flameless cremation, green cremation, biocremation, or Resomation®) is touted as an environmentally friendly alternative to cremation, using little to no natural gas and producing minimal carbon emissions. The process of eliminating the body’s soft tissue requires hot water, alkali salts (e.g. potassium hydroxide and sodium hydroxide), movement of the solution over the body, and time. The deceased pet is placed in a stainless‐steel compartment, usually next to other pets in the machine at the same time, although separated by dividers to reduce the commingling of bone (seeFigure 13.7). When the aquamation unit holds an appropriate amount of predetermined body weight, the salts are added, and the machine begins its cycle. Soft tissue undergoes dissolution to become water, and what’s left is clean, wet bone. The bone is dried and processed into ash.

The water generated by aquamation is known as effluent. It is commonly drained into wastewater but may also be land applied as a soil amendment or bio‐stimulant. If the aftercare company allows, effluent may be given to caregivers who request it for their gardens or plants. Effluent is void of chemicals such as euthanasia solutions, chemotherapy, and other drugs. It is sterile with no bacteria, fungi, viruses, or even prions (responsible for mad cow disease in cattle and scrapie in sheep).

Aquamation may be an attractive option for caregivers looking for a less volatile option compared to cremation. In this author’s experience, some people do not like the idea of burning and would prefer something gentler. Aquamation does not allow for special items to remain with the body during the process. Only the natural body will be placed in the machine. The technician’s role is to explain the available options to caregivers in a supportive and informative way (Communication Corner 13.3).

sidebar.title: Communication Corner 13.3 Example Language to Explain Aquamation to a Caregiver

listitem.para: “Aquamation uses water and salts to gently reduce the body to bone. The bone is then dried and processed into ash.”
“It is similar to what happens to the body during burial, however, aquamation is much faster, taking less than a day compared to what burial does over many years.”
“The ash will be very fine, like baby powder.”
“If you wish to send special items with your pet, the item may be placed near the machine but not in it. Only the natural body will go through the process.”
“The water that’s generated will either go into wastewater to support the local water treatment facility or be spread on the land (depending on the aquamation facilities normal procedure).”

sect2.title: 13.5.4 Body Preservation
sect2.para: Caregivers may desire to preserve their pet’s body through taxidermy or freeze‐drying. Taxidermy is the less common of the two options because it requires the removal of the animal’s skin and external features, which are then placed over a mannequin in a lifelike pose. This has proven challenging due to shrinkage and discoloration. Freeze drying, also known as lyophilization or cryodesiccation, is a low‐temperature dehydration process that involves freezing the body and lowering pressure, thereby removing the icech0025-c13-bib-0006. In other words, the body’s moisture is completely removed, leaving behind a lifelike form in any position the caregiver chooses. The caregiver tells the freeze‐drying company what position they wish, and after many months of undergoing the dehydration process, the deceased pet is returned to the owner for display.

Body preservation is one of the more expensive options for caregivers, however, if it is important to keep their pet looking as they did in life, technicians may inform them of the option. Preparation will include contacting the few freeze‐drying companies that exist in North America (and the world), with consideration for what it may take to ship a frozen deceased pet across country lines. Caregivers will need to think about the position they want their pet and its overall appearance (e.g. sleeping with eyes closed, eyes open with an inquisitive look, playful).

Partial body preservation may also be an attractive option to caregivers. They can elect to keep a part of their pet’s body but not all, and remove it themselves, or ask the veterinary team or aftercare company to assist. In this author’s experience, it is the veterinary team that handles this part due to their anatomy training and access to medical equipment (e.g. sharp knives, extraction tools). Common body parts requested for memorialization include ears, tails, nails, teeth, and skulls. Without some manner of dehydration or formal preservation, any body part with moisture is likely to decompose. If the complete skull is requested, the head will be collected, and the soft tissue removed through chemical dissolution or insect cleaning. What’s left is a dry skull, usually bleached white with the mandible permanently attached. Technicians may be asked to remove a part of a pet’s body. If they are uncomfortable with the task, they can delegate it to their attending veterinarian. Some manner of policy should be in place regarding body part collection so everyone on the hospice team knows what can and cannot be done (Pro Tip 13.2).

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 13.2 Supporting Uncommon Aftercare and Memorialization Requests
sidebar.para: Keep an open and nonjudgmental mind when ascertaining the caregiver’s wishes for less common aftercare and memorialization options.

listitem.para: Simply consider: Is it a reasonable request that is possible to fulfill? How can the EOL care team assist the caregiver in fulfilling this wish? If it is not feasible, is there a feasible alternative in keeping with the spirit of the request?

sect2.title: 13.5.5 Educational Memorial Body Donation
sect2.para: In some communities, there may be the option to donate a deceased pet’s body to a teaching institution. Veterinary colleges are the most common donation site due to the demand for cadavers in veterinary classes. Cadavers are a particularly valuable teaching aid for anatomy, surgery, and procedural labs. In this author’s experience, companion animal cadavers are becoming harder for teaching institutions to locate due to decreased donations from animal shelters.

In a 2023 study from the United Kingdom, researchers looked at the option of body donation among caregivers. Not surprisingly, they found that most caregivers did not know body donation was an option. Many respondents took the opportunity to express a lack of understanding of the process involved in pet cadaver donation and felt that more information and education should be provided to ownersch0025-c13-bib-0007. The largest motivator for caregivers to donate was understanding that they were helping veterinary professionals learn, and if offered, could have their pet’s ashes returned, however, pet ashes given back to the caregiver after donation is not common. If it helps drive donations in areas of the world that need it, technicians may be able to help facilitate such an arrangement. The study also showed that teaching using ethically sourced cadavers is important to caregivers.

Technicians can open discussion around pet body donation at the same time other aftercare options are given (Communication Corner 13.4). Body donation can be included in a handout or listed on a website, explaining what it is and why it’s beneficial. If caregivers elect to donate their pet’s body, technicians will need to prepare the body in accordance with the donation site’s needs. Examples include either freezing the body or keeping it cold but not frozen. The body is ideally stored in a leakproof bag or container, and in some instances, the body may be given heparin to prevent blood clotting. This would be done just before death, during a euthanasia appointment. Technicians can learn such details in advance and be ready to help ensure the body is put to the best use. If the caregiver is expecting the ashes to be returned afterward and the donation site can comply, technicians will be extra vigilant with proper labeling.

sidebar.title: Communication Corner 13.4 Example Language Related to Body Donation

listitem.para: “In our community, we also have the unique option of an educational memorial donation.”
“You may gift your pet’s body to help teach veterinary personnel, to improve their skills.”
“We won’t be able to learn about your pet’s condition, but if that is important, we can arrange for a full necropsy. This is a formal report that tells us what has been causing their illness.”
“After the educational use, the body will be handled according to the teaching site’s normal disposition.”

sect2.title: 13.6 Minimizing Aftercare Mistakes and Exceeding Expectations
sect2.para: Technicians have the opportunity to help caregivers make aftercare choices that align with their values and preferences. Through careful planning, caregivers should have confidence that they made good decisions about the handling of their pet’s body. One of the primary jobs of technicians is to make sure that caregiver wishes are adhered to by the veterinary team and aftercare company. They will double and triple check details, especially in high volume EOL care services where large numbers of pets are dying, either naturally or through euthanasia. Did the caregiver get the pawprint they asked for? Did the team save the clipping of fur as planned? Such questions and details will need to be checked in advance of the body’s disposition.

There may be times when caregivers later question their aftercare choices. It is fairly common for those who have selected to have their pet’s ashes returned to decide they don’t want them after all. In this author’s experience, hospitals regularly report a buildup of unclaimed ashes and are unsure how to manage them. Some cremation and aquamation companies will accept them back to either store them for eventual caregiver pickup or spread them in their standard fashion. Once they are spread, they are unretrievable. Some caregivers give permission to have the ashes spread, but most never respond to calls or emails, which leaves the decision of how best to proceed in the hands of the staff. It’s advisable to include aftercare agreement language that indicates how long ashes will be held for pickup, and where they will be spread if they stay beyond the allowable time (Communication Corner 13.5). Holding ashes for one to six months is common and provides time for grieving caregivers to be emotionally ready to claim them or declare they do not want them. Providing this time is respectful and signifies that the veterinary team understands the complexities of loss.

In a time when meeting expectations is hoped for, caregivers appreciate when EOL care teams go the extra mile to exceed aftercare expectations. Examples of this include returning ashes to clients in private spaces, reviewing the spelling of names for accuracy on keepsakes, and providing kind words of support. Caregivers receiving ashes, memorial items, or preserved body parts are often flooded with emotion as the reality of the death washes over them again. Technicians may use their compassion skills to offer comfort and support. This will be discussed in more detail inChapter 15.

sidebar.title: Communication Corner 13.5 Example Language for Cremation or Aquamation Agreements
sidebar.para: The language included in your aftercare agreements will depend on your aftercare company arrangements, with some examples provided below.

listitem.para: “Ashes will be held at our location for 3 months. After this time, they will be returned to the aftercare company and managed according to their standards.”

“Ashes will be held at our location for 3 months. After this time, they will be spread in accordance with our service’s ash‐spreading policy. Unclaimed ashes are spread in our memorial garden next to the hospital.”
“Ashes will be held at the aftercare facility for 3 months. Unclaimed ashes are spread according to their ash‐spreading policy.”

sect2.title: 13.7 Expected Postmortem Changes and Decomposition
sect2.para: Immediately following the death of a pet, the body will begin to undergo the stages of decay. These changes start simple and rather slowly, giving time for technicians to prepare the body before advanced body breakdown gets underway. The goal is to minimize decay while personnel are working with the body, such as when preparing it for containment and storage at the veterinary hospital, and then later when the body is received at the aftercare facility. When caregivers ask to take the body home for burial or to view it for a short period of time before bringing the body to the aftercare facility themselves, they also appreciate a technician’s tips to maintain a preserved body as long as possible.

emphasis.emphasis: Early Postmortem Physical Changes Observed Shortly After the Death of an Animal Include

listitem.para: Release of bladder and bowel
Eyes remain open
Corneal glazing
Changing the color of the mucous membranes (pink to blue to white)
Fluid release from nose and mouth
Cooling of the extremities
Air sounds from the lungs

emphasis.emphasis: Further Postmortem Physical Changes Prior to Decomposition Include

listitem.para: Pallor mortis: loss of skin and membrane color about 15–25 minutes after death
Rigor mortis : stiffening of muscle due, within minutes to hours of death and resolving after 24–36 hours (Pro Tip 13.3)
Livor mortis : settling of blood in the lower portions of the body, causing a mottled purple discoloration of the skin
Algor mortis : deep reduction in body temperature within a few hours of death

sect2.para: Communication Corner 13.6 offers technicians support in describing the initial post‐mortem changes that caregivers can expect. The emerging theme with these phrases is that everything is normal and natural. Caregivers want to know that what they are seeing and feeling as their pet dies is expected and there is no cause for concern. In this author’s experience, the biggest concern is over post‐death urination and defecation. It is simple to address the issue by placing a protective pad under the body just before death.

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 13.3 Compassionate Positioning of Deceased Bodies
sidebar.para: Assist caregivers in arranging their pet’s position for transport or burial before rigor mortis sets in.

sidebar.title: Communication Corner 13.6 Example Language to Describe and Support Postmortem Changes
sidebar.para: (dependent on the patient’s condition at the time of death, e.g. presence of cancer, fever, and advanced age.)

listitem.para: “Upon their passing (death), the body will slowly start to change.”
“The body will become noticeably cooler to the touch.”
“The body will start to become noticeably firmer over a few hours’ time.”
“It is possible we may see some fluids leave the nose and mouth.”
“It is normal for them to potty (urinate/defecate) as the body releases energy.”
“I’m going to place this towel/pad under their body to keep them dry and protected.”
“As we move her, we may hear some air sounds leaving the chest. This is very natural.”
“His eyes will remain open during his passing and afterward. This is normal.”

sect2.title: 13.7.1 Decomposition
sect2.para: Decomposition is a natural process that reduces the whole body to a more elemental state (seeFigure 13.8). The five stages of decomposition can be summarized as follows:

listitem.para: “Fresh stage”: The body undergoes autolysis when the body’s own enzymes and chemicals begin digesting the body from the inside.

Bloat: The body’s natural bacteria liquify everything they contact. The more active the bacteria, the more gas and odor they produce. Bloat describes the distention of the abdomen where much of the body’s bacteria reside in the gastrointestinal tract. Bloat can be disturbing for caregivers to see and make it hard to move/tuck the body into more pleasing positions.
Active decay: Organisms such as insects and fungi eat at the flesh, reducing it more and more.
Advanced decay: Most remaining tissue is now very dry and brittle. Without the moisture and bacteria, the body has less odor.

sect2.para: It’s important that technicians aiding in the handling of the deceased pet understand these stages of decomposition and how to slow the progression. Depending on the pet’s state of health at the time of death, and how it will be contained afterward, decomposition may be rapid or slow. As a general rule, minimizing physical changes and preserving a pet’s normal appearance is desired (seeFigures 13.9 and 13.10).

emphasis.emphasis: Some Ways to Slow Decomposition Rates Include

listitem.para: Cool the body: The colder the body, the slower the decay. Most veterinary hospitals hold deceased pets in freezing temperatures to slow decomposition. The body will remain in a start of frozen suspension and is ideal for long holding periods. For short‐term holding, refrigeration is adequate. A body may be held in refrigeration for up to seven days in reasonable preservation. If the body is left out in the environment for more than a few hours, it is best to keep it shielded from the sun and hot spaces. Ice packs can be placed near the body to reduce the body temperature.

listitem.para: Dry the body: Moisture should be removed from the body’s exterior when possible. Urine, blood, and stool can be wiped away. While technicians do not remove the fluids from the inside of the body (known as embalming in human deathcare), there is a process known as freeze drying that has been used for pets for long‐term preservation.

Prevent insects: Insects can be attracted to an animal before, during, and after death. A net, sheet, or blanket may be placed over the body to reduce contact surface area. The body may be completely enclosed as added protection. If insects are already on the body, technicians may clean them away using water or alcohol, cloth, or even vacuum suction. Fly larvae (maggots) can grow exceptionally fast and are especially important to remove ch0025-c13-bib-0008. They lead to unwanted tissue destruction before desired aftercare methods begin.
Patients should be handled gently both in life and in death.
Caregivers expect a high level of care from animal hospice technicians.
Technicians have an opportunity to tour local aftercare services so they may share important information with caregivers.
Technicians may be responsible for ensuring aftercare wishes are properly carried out on behalf of the caregiver.
Modern aftercare approaches include offering more choices to caregivers and reducing what the veterinary team manages.
